newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippine 91-day T-bill rate falls to 10.625 pct.
newsitem.headline: Philippine 91-day T-bill rate falls to 10.625 pct.

text.p: The Philippine bellwether 91-day Treasury bill rate dropped to an average of 10.625 percent during the regular weekly auction from 10.661 percent last week, the Bureau of Treasury said on Monday.
The other maturities likewise fell. The 182-day T-bill rate slipped to an average of 10.986 percent from 11.073; and the 364-day rate dipped to 11.491 from 11.532 percent.,
A foreign bank dealer said the government fetched lower rates on its T-bill rates because of its improved credit rating.

Last Friday, the U.S.-based Standard and Poor's Corp upgraded the Philippines' peso-denominated debt to A-minus/A-1 from BBB-plus/A-3 respectively. Its long-term foreign currency debt was also raised to BB-plus from BB.
"Investors from abroad are looking at the Philippines as a better investment opportunity," the dealer said.
Traders said the continued high liquidity in the market was also a factor in nudging rates lower.
The auction had 20.350 billion pesos worth of tenders, of which 4.5 billion pesos were accepted.
The one-year bills attracted the most number of bids at 7.650 billion pesos, of which two billion pesos were awarded.
The 182-day bills, which had sales of 1.5 billion pesos, generated 6.920 billion pesos of bids.
And the 91-day bill drew 5.780 billion pesos of tenders, of which one billion pesos were awarded.
